unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Constructing Certain Types of Mean Intervals: Respect Your Boss
question_text:
An insurance company is assessing two of its regional managers (Manager $A$ and Manager $B$) on how well-respected they are by their employees. The insurance company randomly selects $40$ employees from both regions.
They ask the employees to rate how much they respect their managers on a $1-10$ scale, with $1$ representing no respect and $10$ representing the utmost respect. Here are the summary results:
Which of the following represents a $99\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the averages between how much company $A$'s employees respect their manager when compared with company $B$'s?
Which of the following represents a $99\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the averages between how much company $A$'s employees respect their manager when compared with company $B$'s?
solution:
This is a $2$-sample $t$-interval for means. It is $2$-sample instead of paired because the groups are independent, meaning the employees' decisions from company $A$ do not affect the employees' decisions from company $B$.

This is a $t$-interval, since we are using the sample standard deviation (standard error) and not the population standard deviation. As a reminder, Mr. T is mean, so use $t$-intervals for means.

Put that data into your calculator and run the $t$-interval, or you could do the work out by hand

If you have TI-84 go to Stat, then Test, then 2 sample T-interval. Choose the Stats over the Data and enter your information. Hit enter to calculate.
